turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: Uncle Maurice, you're wearing sneakers?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: High-top Nike Cross-Trainers with heel support and air-cushioned soles.  They're nasty.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: And your store?  What about your new store?  What about all your dreams?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I have new dreams now.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: I don't accept that.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Maybe one day -- after you've been married twenty years you'll understand.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: Uncle Maurice -- I spent all our frequent flyer miles on a one way ticket here... I have a rented car outside, just listen to me.  Come back with me now, and if you still want to do something like this in a year -- maybe we'll plan a car trip across the country -- Gerald and I will come along --

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I have to walk -- by myself -- all the way -- every inch.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: It's impossible.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: It's what she asked for... It's what I'm going to do.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: She was being symbolic.  What if she asked you to fly to the moon?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: You'd be visiting me at Nasa.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: What if you don't make it?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I'll make it.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: If you really want to do this... plan it out.  Rest up.  Train for it.  Build up your body.  Plan every stop along the way.  How much money?  Time?  Really do it properly.  This is all so -- by the seat of your pants.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: No it's not.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: Why did you take the back roads here?  They're not safe.  You'd know that if you'd planned.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I've all ready gone six hundred miles... I can't do it again.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: If you can't redo these six hundred miles when you're rested and ready, how are you possible going to walk another two thousand-five hundred miles in your present condition?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Nothing's going to happen.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: Uncle, the way I was told, if that police car didn't happen down that road, you would be dead right now. That guy Denny, had jumped bail in another state, he's dangerous... They'll be other Dennys, if you don't plan.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Are you two planning kids?

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: Maybe later.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: You should definitely have children.  They're really special.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: I don't think you realize how serious this is Uncle.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: How serious is it?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Then it'll have to wait until I finish.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I finish the walk, and then we may take all the chances we want.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: Listen to me very carefully, because I don't want you to misunderstand me... The walk is over Uncle Maurice.  Done. Finished.  You've made it to California, it was a miracle, now let's try to save your life.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I'm completing the walk.  I'm almost there.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I have to finish first.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: I won't let you die.

turns.speaker: DALLY
turns.text: What would you like us to do?

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: Put out a P.B.S.... Or whatever it's called.

turns.speaker: DALLY
turns.text: A.P.B.... He isn't breaking any law.  He's a grown man... He can crawl on his hands and knees to China if that's what he wants to do.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: Sergeant, I'm a psychologist and I know the difference between normal whims people have and actions that clearly display psychological problems... My uncle lost his wife and it devastated him.

turns.speaker: DALLY
turns.text: We're very sorry about that.  Some of our men were on the scene of the accident.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: I think my uncle is suffering from a condition called Mania which is linked with depression.  It is a time when an individual will act over-confident, and will act out impractical, grandiose plans. Sometimes these plans can be dangerous.

turns.speaker: DALLY
turns.text: How long does this... Mania last?

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: A couple days to a few months if untreated.

turns.speaker: DALLY
turns.text: Look, I'll see if anyone has spotted him recently.  If I get any information, I'll call you.

turns.speaker: ADELLE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: DALLY
turns.text: Don't wait by the phone.  If he's really been walking this whole time, he's out of our jurisdiction...

turns.speaker: DENNY
turns.text: Mine.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Are you and your friends planning on driving soon?

turns.speaker: DENNY
turns.text: Are you a preacher?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: No, I just don't want anybody dying because I didn't say something when I had the chance.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: This is Indiana -- nothing's going to happen to you.

turns.speaker: DENNY
turns.text: You need a ride, Preacher?

turns.speaker: DENNY
turns.text: A wife?... Did someone piss drunk run into your wife?  Crushed her like a bug.  Snapped her bones?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: That's enough.

turns.speaker: DENNY
turns.text: Oh the preacher's getting angry again...  Tell me something.  Did she die instantly or did she feel every torn muscle and shattered bone? Were you there to help her?  Or were you safe at home when the windshield sliced into her face --

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I'll kill you!

turns.speaker: DR. RAY
turns.text: The normal amount of build up in your arteries has been aggravated by over exertion.  This is called, "Claudication,"  As a result, there isn't enough circulation to your body.  That accounts for the discoloration in your extremities and the muscle spasms I'm sure you've encountered.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Can it kill me?

turns.speaker: DR. RAY
turns.text: It can, but it'll have to wait in line.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: What steps do we take now?

turns.speaker: DR. RAY
turns.text: We operate.  We find the artery in the brain and close the bleeding... I just did this procedure on a Senator and he's doing fine.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: What are the odds?  Do I have a fifty-fifty chance of surviving the operation?

turns.speaker: DR. RAY
turns.text: It's hard to say.  It's a delicate surgery.  There's no getting around the fact that it's a very high-risk situation.

turns.speaker: DR. ROYCE
turns.text: So what's the deal Maurice?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Pardon?

turns.speaker: DR. ROYCE
turns.text: I mean why the sudden voluntary visit  -- usually it takes gun- point to get you in here...

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Routine, I assure you.  I just wanted to gage my health.  Am I healthy?

turns.speaker: DR. ROYCE
turns.text: Yes -- you are.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I'm going to ask you a question that may sound peculiar.

turns.speaker: DR. ROYCE
turns.text: I know what you're getting at.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: You do?

turns.speaker: DR. ROYCE
turns.text: I've seen it before.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: You have?

turns.speaker: DR. ROYCE
turns.text: You're feeling old and you want to start exercising.  A lot of men your age feel the need to recapture their youth.  Don't feel embarrassed about it.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: DR. ROYCE
turns.text: You should start slow and easy -- fifteen minutes a day.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: No.  How far in one attempt -- what's the farthest someone like myself could walk?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Just for curiosity sake that's all?

turns.speaker: DR. ROYCE
turns.text: I don't know -- maybe twenty miles... Of course I'm not recommending that... if someone like you had to I mean... that's how far they'd probably get before encountering serious physical walls.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Twenty miles?  I see.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: The flowers... they're beautiful.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: You thought I sent them?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: There was no card.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Have I forgotten something?  Is this a special day?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: It's just a regular day.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: It's a special day isn't it?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Well, I'm sure it's not Christmas, because you'd be worried about how much money we don't have to spend on each other... I know it's not New Years, because you'd be going on and on about wearing a tuxedo and how much you don't like to dance... and I'm sure it's not our anniversary, because I didn't find an envelope with a hundred dollars cash on my bureau with a note that says, 'Pick out something pretty'... Yes -- Maurice -- I'm virtually certain it's not a special day today.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Ellen?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: The new store?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Honey, I told you.  If it makes you happy, we should just do it.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: It's a tremendous amount of work -- moving.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: We can do it together.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: ... Love is shown through actions not just words.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: What's that?  That's not a fortune... You will be rich... That's a fortune.  What you have is a statement.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: What it is -- is the truth.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I don't follow.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Is this going to be similar to the flower incident?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Sometimes people need to see things done for them -- because sooner or later they don't believe the words anymore.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: You don't think I love you?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: I want to be shown...  Maurice would you do anything for me?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Anything?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: What do you want from me?  Would I swim across an ocean for you?... Would I walk across the United States for you?  Yes... Yes I would.  You know that.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: No I don't.  I don't even know if you'd walk across the street for me.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Why do you polish that thing all the time?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: You're talking to me?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Why do you polish it?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: A Book Society Award is a very prestigious thing.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Why are you polishing it -- in bed -- in your pajamas -- at 11:15 at night?  Are you going to show it to someone?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Then why?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: There's no reason.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Exactly.  No reason.  No occasion. It just makes you feel good to do something for it, to express your pride and affection for it some how...  How come you'd do that for a piece of metal and not for me?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I do love you... very, very much.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Show me.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I will -- I promise.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Walk with me?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: You like to take walks?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: No.  But I want to take a walk with you.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: It's one of those thoughts you keep to yourself.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Please tell me.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I thought we both wanted the same things.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: I've changed my mind.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: You can't change your mind.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: I want children.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: You've just decided, is that right?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Ellen, there are two kinds of people in the world --

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Please not, 'The two kinds of people' speech.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: ... People that were made to be parents, and people who were not made to be parents... My parents, were people who were not made to be parents but had kids anyway.  I don't want us to be that way Ellen.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: You can change.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Face it Ellen, I'm not the type of person who reads bedtime stories. But you love me anyway.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Don't be so sure.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: It must've hit the window... I think its neck is broken.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Don't bring it in here -- it probably has all kinds of diseases.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: It isn't going to make it Ellen. Let the poor thing go quietly.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: It'll make it.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Your father?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: He's plastered.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: That's okay -- really it is.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: No it's not.  He should be here with me now, not trying to find some fucking bottle of Johnny Walker.  He's never been there for me.  I've always been alone.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: I think it's a different place for each person.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Did you have a dream?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: I know where my heaven is.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Pacifica, California.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Why there?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: When I was ten, my family lived in Pacifica for a year.  I used to go to the beach everyday that summer. I never felt so happy, carefree. It was a magic place for me... That's where my heaven will be.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Maurice?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: If I die, you'll know where to look for me?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Go to sleep Ellen.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: No really, if God takes us away from each other, you know where to look now?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: The beach of Pacifica, California.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: What did they ask?

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: If I had seen you.  By the way I'm sorry about your wife.  They told me.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Thank you... I'm sorry you had to lie.  It must have been difficult.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: I asked the officers if you had committed some crime... If they had said 'yes', you would be speaking with them right now.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: To where?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Pacifica, California.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: From where?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Do you believe a person's soul lives on after their death?

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: Most certainly.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: And that that soul takes part of the person they were on this earth with them.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: That's a reasonable assumption.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I don't want my wife's soul having any doubts.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: Doubts?  About what?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: About my love for her.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: You don't have to prove anything to her.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I'm not proving to her.  I'm showing her.  And I know I don't have to.  I want to.  I've realized, love is about giving. I'm alive, I can still give to her. I want to give her everything I can.

turns.speaker: HANSEN
turns.text: What's his story?

turns.speaker: TANDY
turns.text: His name is Maurice.  He's dancing around everything else.

turns.speaker: HANSEN
turns.text: Red flag, man.

turns.speaker: TANDY
turns.text: If he's in trouble with the law -- fine.  Not our problem.  He yanked two people from a car wreck, let's give him some space.

turns.speaker: HANSEN
turns.text: Red flags man.

turns.speaker: TANDY
turns.text: Not our problem.

turns.speaker: HANSEN
turns.text: Why so vague?  Why so evasive?  He could be somebody hot.

turns.speaker: TANDY
turns.text: Not our problem.

turns.speaker: HANSEN
turns.text: It's going to look beautiful when he turns out to be that animal who paid a visit to the Steadman's house.

turns.speaker: TANDY
turns.text: This guy's not a murderer.

turns.speaker: HANSEN
turns.text: If he is, half the town has seen us take him out for dinner like a couple of jack-asses.

turns.speaker: HANSEN
turns.text: A marriage certificate?  Who the hell carries their marriage certificate around?

turns.speaker: TANDY
turns.text: Maurice and Ellen Parker... it was issued in Philly... Mr. Maurice Parker has come a long way from home.  Why?

turns.speaker: TANDY
turns.text: Hansen's whipped.  Has to call his wife every two hours or she'll go ballistic when he gets home.

turns.speaker: HANSEN
turns.text: P-A-R-K-E-R.  Right.  Get on the horn with Philly.  Call me here.

turns.speaker: HANSEN
turns.text: I'm going to drop off Tandy at the station and then drop you back.

turns.speaker: TANDY
turns.text: That's all right isn't it?

turns.speaker: TANDY
turns.text: Shit!  He jumped!

turns.speaker: HANSEN
turns.text: Jumped where?

turns.speaker: TANDY
turns.text: Out of the car.  He jumped out of the god damn car!

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Well, hello.

turns.speaker: ISAAC
turns.text: I'm Isaac... I'm three.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I'm Maurice Parker... I'm much older than three.  Are your parents home?

turns.speaker: ISAAC
turns.text: You know what, I can play baseball with my brothers when I'm bigger.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Is that right?

turns.speaker: ISAAC
turns.text: You know what... I'm just little now, but I'll be big soon.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: You'll probably be bigger than your brothers.

turns.speaker: ISAAC
turns.text: Yeah!

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I thought you were asleep.

turns.speaker: ISAAC
turns.text: You know what... I remembered you were here and I woke up.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Your parents would want you to be in bed.

turns.speaker: ISAAC
turns.text: You tell stories?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Oh no... I'm not good at that. Very bad in fact...

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: There was a boy named Isaac who wanted to play baseball, but he was too small and no one would let him play... but he kept practicing by himself -- waiting... He went to every game and sat in the stands with his glove.

turns.speaker: ISAAC
turns.text: You know what... maybe I ran onto the field and hit a home run.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Who's telling this story?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Anyway, Big Billy needed another player so he yelled into the stands.  'Who can play baseball?' And there was a little voice that yelled out, 'Me, I can play.' Everyone turned to see a little boy standing with a glove.

turns.speaker: ISAAC
turns.text: That's me.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Right.  But everyone saw how small Isaac was and laughed... but not Big Billy.  He stared at Isaac carefully and then told him to join the game.  It came to the end of the game.  It was the eleventh or twelfth inning or whatever is the last inning of a game...

turns.speaker: ISAAC
turns.text: Nine.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Okay nine.  Big Billy's team was losing and he was on base.  That's when Isaac came up.  He could barely hold the bat... Big Billy winked at Isaac... The ball was pitched -- Isaac hit the ball hard. It soared up and out over the stadium.  Everyone cheered.  Isaac hit a home run and won the game. After the game, Isaac asked Big Billy why he let he play.  Big Billy smiled and said, I wasn't always Big Billy, I was Little Billy first... Isaac and Big Billy went off after the game and read a classic book together.  The end.

turns.speaker: ISAAC
turns.text: You know what -- that was a really good story... Tell it again.

turns.speaker: JOSELLE
turns.text: Each inch represents 150 miles...

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Making the grand total?

turns.speaker: JOSELLE
turns.text: Damn baby, relax.  I'm getting to it.  From Philadelphia following the route highlighted to Pacifica California -- you're traveling an estimated three thousand two hundred miles...

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Three thousand miles?... How many times does twenty go into three thousand?

turns.speaker: JOSELLE
turns.text: What was that?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Perhaps there's another route?

turns.speaker: JOSELLE
turns.text: This is the route approved by triple A.  Even if you followed back roads the entire way, you'd still be looking at roughly the same distance...

turns.speaker: JOSELLE
turns.text: Don't worry baby, it shouldn't take you more than five days if you just stop to sleep and eat.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: By car right?

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: This story is big huh?

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Mammoth.

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: The Gazette's small huh?

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: What are you saying?  This story is too big for this paper?

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: Umm, no.  It's just that --

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: God damn, you're right... You don't say much Michelle, but what you say is golden.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Michelle, breathe... that's it, what is it, talk to me.

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: Umm, Coalville Utah.

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: Umm, he's going to make it isn't he?

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Lizy, Eliza... Elizabeth Bennett...  Pride and Prejudice.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: You're amazing.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: It has to be a full character's name.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: They called her 'Lizy' in the book...  Sorry I was late.  My jeep died on the way over from the paper.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: They printed your article on, 'Dry Verses Can Dog Food'... Very enlightening.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Pulitzer, here I come.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Never have children.  If they're not a burden to you, they're a burden to someone else.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: I want to reach people.  Nobody listens to me.  This is my way to reach them.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: To reach people, you have to feel something first... You write about the wrong things.  How can you feel for dog food?  The people at the Gazette don't respect it, and neither do you.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: This is a ghost town.  Nothing ever happens.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Write from your heart.  That's why the classics are great.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Are you firing me?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: No.  No... I won't be here for a while.  The store will be closed in the interim.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: You going on a trip Mr. Parker?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: California.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: When are you leaving?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Tomorrow.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I'm walking there Kris.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Walking where?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: California.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: The hairs on my arm are standing up... Something strange is happening.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I always knew you had good instincts...  Goodbye Kris.  I'll see you when I get back.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Phileas Fogg?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: ... Round The World In Eighty Days. ... Hello Kris.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: You're amazing... What are you doing Mr. Parker?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I told you.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: You're walking to California?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Pacifica, California -- it's a coastal city.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Oh, a coastal city.  That's good.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Ellen told me that she didn't know if I loved her.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: She knew you loved her.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: She wasn't certain... I never really showed her.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: I'm really lost.  What does this have to do with walking?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I said, 'I would do anything for her'... and she didn't believe me. I said, 'I'd walk across the country for her'... she didn't believe me.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I need to show her how much I love her Kris.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Why know?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Because I should have shown her before... Everyday, I should have shown her.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Pacifica, California... that's a long ways away.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: So I've been informed.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Ellen got up every morning and went to the corner store to get me my bread for breakfast... Everyday. Now that's about a quarter mile each way... 17 years... that comes to about three thousand miles...  And you know what Kris?

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: What Mr. Parker?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: She never ate a slice.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Tom Joad?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: ... The Grapes of Wrath.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: You're amazing.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I missed you Kris.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: I missed you to Mr. Parker.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Adelle told me, your writing is going well.  The Crusader for social issues and all.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: You were right.  From the heart is always better.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I haven't been too punctual with the rent.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: I was thinking you could open another store with investors.  I'm sure a lot of people would want to get involved with you now.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Are they standing?

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Saluting.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Come on Mr. Parker.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: What, come on?

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: I can't do it.  I want you to finish, but I want you to live more.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: We do the operation after I finish. I can't risk not finishing... I thought you understood what I was doing.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: I do.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Why in God's name did you fly all the way here then?

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Don't do this.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: ... To look me in the eye and say what's important to you isn't as important to me?  To tell me you know what's best?  To tell me life is more precious than what I feel for my wife?

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: Mr. Parker, you can yell at me, if it'll help.  But I'm not risking your life.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: It's mine to risk.

turns.speaker: KRIS
turns.text: She knows you love her Mr. Parker. She knows now.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: No more words.  Until I touch the ocean with my hands... it's all just words.

turns.speaker: STEPHANIE
turns.text: There are a lot of people worried about you.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Where am I?

turns.speaker: STEPHANIE
turns.text: In a hospital.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Which hospital?  Did you take me back?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: What do your friends call you?

turns.speaker: STEPHANIE
turns.text: Steph.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Do you have a car, Steph?

turns.speaker: STEPHANIE
turns.text: You're in pain.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I need your help.

turns.speaker: STEPHANIE
turns.text: They told me, you might try to talk me into something... You need to rest Mr. Parker... It's for your own good.  I've been following your story for a long while.  It's a beautiful thing you did.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: You ever lose somebody Stephanie?

turns.speaker: STEPHANIE
turns.text: Mr. Parker, I'm supposed to give you your fish sticks.

turns.speaker: STEPHANIE
turns.text: ... My father.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Did you tell him everything you wanted to?  Did you do everything you could while he was here?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: You're going to have a lot of work to do when I get back.

turns.speaker: STEPHANIE
turns.text: Someone should be with you.

turns.speaker: OLD WOMAN
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: OLD WOMAN
turns.text: Is it a boy or a girl?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Oh, that's not mine.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: I don't have kids.

turns.speaker: OLD WOMAN
turns.text: You should.  Children are a blessing from God.  I have four.
